botanical_details.genus: Vaccinium can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees, with simple leaves and small, bell- or urn-shaped flowers followed by juicy, sometimes edible berries

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant a sheltered site in well-drained, moisture-retentive, acidic soil, (pH 4.5-5.5) in sun or part shade. Alternatively grow in containers or raised beds filled with ericaceous compost such as John Innes Ericaceous. Pot grown plants benefit from winter protection. For optimal pollination and yield plant three different cultivars. For further cultivation details see blueberry cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Take 10-15cm (4-6in) softwood cuttings in late spring or semi-ripe cuttings in early summer
how_to_grow.pruning: More mature plants benefit from regular pruning, see pruning blueberries
how_to_grow.pests: Watch out for vine weevil, especially if container grown
how_to_grow.diseases: Can be affected by powdery mildews. Chlorosis due iron and mangenese deficiency may be a problem - see nutrient deficiency
